paper_title: Cross Helicity and the Helium Abundance as an In Situ Metric of Solar Wind Acceleration

figures.short_title: Bimodal Solar Wind Speed Distribution Reveals Two Populations During Solar Minimum

summary.what_we_see: This elegant probability distribution plot reveals the speeds at which the solar wind—a continuous stream of charged particles from the Sun—reaches Earth's orbit, based on 28 years of observations (1994-2022) from NASA's Wind spacecraft. The vertical axis uses logarithmic scaling to show probability density spanning six orders of magnitude (one-in-a-million to one-in-a-hundred), while the horizontal axis displays solar wind speed from 200 to 800 kilometers per second. Three overlapping curves paint different pictures of the solar wind: a green dashed line representing all data collected shows a single broad peak around 350-400 km/s with a long tail extending to 700+ km/s; an orange dash-dotted line capturing solar maximum periods (when the Sun is most active) traces a similar single-peaked shape; but a solid black line showing only solar minimum periods (when the Sun is quietest) reveals a dramatically different structure—two distinct peaks, one centered at roughly 355 km/s and another at approximately 622 km/s, separated by a valley around 480 km/s. This "bimodal" distribution during solar minimum resembles two bell curves side-by-side rather than one smooth hump, indicating the solar wind arrives at Earth in two distinct flavors during these quiet periods. The graph's logarithmic vertical scale allows both the dominant slow wind peak (occurring about 1% of the time) and the less common but substantial fast wind peak (occurring roughly 0.1% of the time) to be visible simultaneously, along with the rare extreme speeds exceeding 700 km/s that appear at probability densities below one-in-ten-thousand.
summary.the_finding: During solar minimum—the quiet phase of the Sun's 11-year magnetic activity cycle—the solar wind measured at Earth's orbit splits cleanly into two populations with characteristic speeds of 355±44 km/s (slow wind) and 622±58 km/s (fast wind), separated by a transition zone around 484 km/s where the two Gaussian-like distributions intersect. This bimodal structure vanishes when you mix data from all solar cycle phases (green dashed line) or look only at solar maximum (orange line), both showing single broad peaks that smear the two populations together. The dual-peaked structure isn't subtle—the valley between peaks dips to roughly one-tenth the height of the slow wind peak, representing a genuine depletion of intermediate-speed observations rather than a smooth continuum. Statistically, the slow wind peak dominates in terms of occurrence rate, appearing about ten times more frequently than the fast wind peak (comparing probability densities of ~10^-2 versus ~10^-3), yet both populations contribute substantially to the solar wind measured at 1 AU (Earth's distance from the Sun). The transition speed of 484 km/s, where these two populations have equal probability, falls roughly midway between the peaks in speed space but corresponds to a probability density closer to the fast wind peak than the slow wind peak, indicating the transition is relatively sharp rather than gradual. Beyond 700 km/s, all three curves (all data, solar max, and solar min) converge to similarly low probabilities below 10^-4, suggesting these extreme speeds—while rare—occur with comparable frequency regardless of solar cycle phase, hinting at transient events like coronal mass ejections that inject high-speed plasma throughout the solar cycle.
summary.why_it_matters: This bimodal speed distribution during solar minimum provides the observational foundation for one of space physics' central paradigms: the solar wind originates from fundamentally different source regions on the Sun with distinct acceleration mechanisms, and these sources become spatially segregated during quiet solar periods. The slow wind peak at 355 km/s corresponds to plasma originating from magnetically closed loop structures near the Sun's equator—complex regions where magnetic field lines arch back to the solar surface, confining plasma in helmet streamers that slowly release material through reconnection and other processes. The fast wind peak at 622 km/s traces plasma from magnetically open polar coronal holes—simpler magnetic structures where field lines extend into interplanetary space, allowing plasma to freely stream outward and accelerate to high speeds through mechanisms still debated (possibly involving Alfvén waves, which are magnetic oscillations propagating along field lines). During solar minimum, the Sun's magnetic field adopts a relatively simple dipole-like structure with polar coronal holes at high latitudes and equatorial streamers at low latitudes, causing Earth—orbiting near the Sun's equatorial plane—to alternately sample slow equatorial wind and fast polar wind as the Sun rotates every 27 days, producing the two-peaked distribution. During solar maximum, the magnetic field becomes chaotic with coronal holes appearing at all latitudes and streamers fragmenting, mixing the two wind types and washing out the bimodal structure. For this paper's central investigation, the bimodal distribution establishes critical reference speeds: the two peaks (355 and 622 km/s) and their intersection (484 km/s) serve as benchmarks against which to compare the newly discovered helium saturation speed (433 km/s, presented in later figures), revealing that the compositional transition from variable to saturated helium content occurs just below the slow-fast transition speed, suggesting helium abundance probes the same source region dichotomy but from a different physical perspective. The collapse of the bimodal structure when mixing solar cycle phases (green dashed line) underscores why careful phase selection matters for solar wind studies—averaging over solar maximum and minimum obscures the underlying physics by blending fundamentally different plasma populations. For space weather applications, recognizing that Earth encounters two distinct solar wind regimes during solar minimum enables better forecasting: slow wind brings higher plasma density and embedded magnetic structures that can trigger moderate geomagnetic disturbances, while fast wind streams deliver sustained energy that heats Earth's outer atmosphere and can cause periodic geomagnetic storms when they collide with preceding slow wind, creating compression regions that arrive at Earth with predictable ~27-day recurrence matching the solar rotation period.

figures.short_title: Cartoon Revealing Where Helium Abundance and Cross Helicity Are Imprinted on Solar Wind

summary.what_we_see: This conceptual diagram illustrates the Sun's inner atmosphere in cross-section, showing how the solar wind acquires two of its key observable properties—helium abundance and cross helicity (Alfvenicity)—at different heights above the solar surface as plasma accelerates outward. The left side displays the Sun's photosphere (visible surface) in yellow-orange, transitioning through thin atmospheric layers labeled in green text: the chromosphere (a region a few thousand kilometers thick where temperature suddenly jumps from 6,000 to 20,000 Kelvin), the transition region (a razor-thin zone spanning just a few hundred kilometers where temperature skyrockets from 20,000 K to over a million Kelvin), and extending into the low corona where closed orange magnetic loops arch back to the surface while open red magnetic field lines stretch into interplanetary space. Three critical surfaces are marked by vertical dashed lines with labels: the green dashed line marks the chromosphere/transition region where helium abundance (A_He) is set through ionization processes; the cyan dashed line indicates the sonic surface (r_c) where the solar wind's speed crosses the sound speed (~150,000 km altitude); and the purple dashed line shows the Alfvén surface (r_A) where the wind speed exceeds the Alfvén speed (speed at which magnetic disturbances propagate), magnetically disconnecting the plasma from the Sun at roughly 10-20 solar radii. Between the sonic and Alfvén surfaces, a blue-purple shaded region is labeled "Cross Helicity |σ_c|" indicating where Alfvén waves imprint their signature correlation between magnetic and velocity fluctuations. Blue arrows of increasing size illustrate solar wind speed accelerating with distance, growing larger from left to right, with text noting this acceleration continues through switchback decay. The diagram shows both closed field topology (orange loops confined near the Sun) and open field topology (red lines extending to the right edge), with the wind accelerating differently along each geometry.
summary.the_finding: This cartoon encodes a fundamental insight: the two plasma properties used to classify solar wind in this paper—helium abundance and cross helicity—are physically imprinted on the solar wind at vastly different heights in the solar atmosphere, yet both carry information about the source region's magnetic topology that persists all the way to Earth's orbit 150 million kilometers away. Helium abundance gets "locked in" extremely close to the Sun—below the sonic surface in the chromosphere and transition region (green dashed line at ~2,000-10,000 km altitude, barely visible on solar radius scales)—where helium atoms are ionized by the intense radiation and thermal energy, determining what fraction of helium ions will be available to flow into the solar wind. Once set, this compositional ratio remains essentially frozen because the plasma densities drop so dramatically with altitude that further ionization or recombination becomes negligible. In stark contrast, cross helicity (the correlation between magnetic and velocity fluctuations that measures Alfvenicity) is established much higher—between the sonic surface (cyan line) and Alfvén surface (purple line), spanning roughly 1-20 solar radii (700,000 to 14 million km altitude)—where Alfvén waves generated in the low corona can propagate both toward and away from the Sun, creating the characteristic correlation or anti-correlation that defines σ_c. Above the Alfvén surface, the solar wind becomes magnetically disconnected from the Sun, meaning Alfvén waves can only propagate in one direction (away from Sun), so cross helicity can only decay, not change fundamentally. The diagram reveals that despite being set at such different heights, both properties correlate with source region magnetic topology: closed orange loops (which trap plasma) versus open red lines (which release plasma freely), explaining why combining A_He and |σ_c| measurements at 1 AU provides a remote diagnostic of conditions ~10-20,000 km versus ~10 million km above the photosphere. The increasing size of blue velocity arrows illustrates that solar wind continues accelerating even beyond the critical surfaces through Alfvénic structure decay (switchbacks), reaching observed speeds of 300-700 km/s at 1 AU despite crossing the sonic point at only ~100-150 km/s.
summary.why_it_matters: This conceptual framework transforms what would otherwise be abstract plasma parameters—helium-to-hydrogen ratio and normalized cross helicity—into powerful remote sensing tools that probe physical conditions at vastly different layers of the solar atmosphere, regions we cannot directly measure with spacecraft. The chromosphere and transition region where helium abundance is set lie so deep in the Sun's gravitational well and radiation environment that no human-made instrument has ever measured them in situ; even Parker Solar Probe, which will eventually skim to within 9 solar radii of the photosphere, will never reach the ~1.003 solar radii altitude of the chromosphere. Yet by measuring helium abundance at Earth's orbit, we can infer whether the wind originated from a source region with sufficient energy to ionize and accelerate helium (open field coronal holes, which have higher temperatures and simpler geometry) versus regions where energy is insufficient and helium either isn't ionized or serves as an energy sink that prevents its own acceleration (closed field loops, which are cooler and more complex). Similarly, cross helicity measured at 1 AU preserves information about wave generation and propagation processes occurring between 1-20 solar radii, altitudes where the solar wind acceleration actually happens but which we can only observe remotely via coronagraph images—images that show plasma structures but cannot measure wave properties. The vertical separation of these two diagnostic heights (chromosphere at ~2,000 km versus Alfvén surface at ~14 million km—a factor of 7,000 difference) is precisely what makes their combination powerful: helium probes the initial energy partitioning and ionization state in the low atmosphere, while cross helicity probes the wave-driven acceleration processes in the extended corona, together constraining both the starting conditions and the acceleration mechanism. For understanding solar wind acceleration—arguably the central unsolved problem in space physics—this dual-height diagnostic breaks degeneracies that plague single-parameter studies: a high-speed wind could result from either high initial energy (detectable via high A_He) or efficient wave-driven acceleration (detectable via high |σ_c|), and only by measuring both can we distinguish these scenarios. The diagram also explains why Alfvénicity can only decay above the Alfvén surface: in sub-Alfvénic regions (below purple line), magnetic tension dominates over inertia, allowing waves to propagate bidirectionally and maintain strong correlations, but in super-Alfvénic regions (above purple line), inertia dominates and backward-propagating waves cannot exist, so turbulent cascade and stream interactions can only weaken the correlation, never strengthen it. This one-way evolution means that high |σ_c| at 1 AU unambiguously indicates a source region with strong Alfvénic character, whereas low |σ_c| could indicate either weak source region Alfvenicity or strong initial Alfvenicity that has decayed—a distinction clarified by combining with helium measurements. For mission planning, this diagram justifies why solar wind composition and magnetic field measurements at any heliocentric distance—whether from Wind at 1 AU, Parker Solar Probe at 0.1 AU, or future missions at 0.05 AU—carry valuable diagnostic power: the signatures are set closer to the Sun and simply propagate outward, meaning closer measurements don't fundamentally change what you learn about source regions, though they do reduce the decorrelation from turbulence and stream interactions during transit.

figures.short_title: Helium Abundance Saturates at 4.19% Above 433 km/s Solar Wind Speed

summary.what_we_see:
This two-dimensional histogram maps 28 years of solar wind measurements into a color-coded density plot. The horizontal axis spans speeds from 200 to 800 km/s. The vertical axis shows helium abundance from 0% to 10%, representing the percentage of helium atoms relative to hydrogen.

The plot is divided into vertical columns by speed. Each column's color intensity is normalized to its own maximum, so bright yellow shows the most common helium value for that speed. This normalization reveals compositional trends that would otherwise be obscured by occurrence rates.

In the slowest wind (200-400 km/s), the bright yellow band rises steadily from near-zero helium at 200 km/s to approximately 4% at 400 km/s. Above 430 km/s, the yellow band abruptly flattens into a horizontal plateau at roughly 4.2%, extending to 800 km/s with no further increase. Green lines bracket the standard deviation range. A pink dash-dotted line shows a two-piece linear fit with a transition at 433 km/s.
summary.the_finding:
Helium abundance exhibits a dramatic transition at 433 plus or minus 4 km/s. Below this speed, helium increases monotonically from essentially zero in the slowest wind to 4.19% at the transition. The climb rate is roughly 0.035% per km/s. Above this speed, helium saturates at 4.19% and remains constant across the entire fast wind regime up to 800 km/s.

This saturation value of 4.19% corresponds to roughly 49% of the Sun's photospheric helium abundance. Fast solar wind is systematically depleted in helium relative to the solar surface, though far less depleted than slow wind below 350 km/s.

The sharpness of the transition is remarkable. The two-piece linear fit captures the trend almost perfectly with just four parameters. The spread in helium abundance is much larger in slow wind than fast wind. Below 400 km/s, helium varies from nearly zero to 6-7% at any given speed. Above 500 km/s, the range narrows to less than 1 percentage point.
summary.why_it_matters:
This discovery provides a compositional fingerprint that sharply divides two physically distinct populations. The 433 km/s saturation speed falls just below the traditional 450-500 km/s threshold for separating slow and fast wind. Helium composition transitions slightly before the speed transition, offering advance warning of changing source regions.

The saturation behavior reveals fundamentally different acceleration mechanisms. In slow wind from magnetically closed loops, helium abundance varies wildly because energy availability depends sensitively on local magnetic topology and heating rates. In fast wind from open coronal holes, helium saturates because sufficient energy exists to ionize and accelerate helium uniformly.

The low variability in fast wind helium versus high variability in slow wind independently confirms the source region dichotomy. Coronal holes are relatively homogeneous structures with stable magnetic geometry. Equatorial streamers and closed loop regions exhibit complex, time-variable topology.

For practical applications, this threshold enables simple operational classification. Spacecraft measuring solar wind with helium rising toward 4% are sampling closed field regions. When helium saturates at 4.2%, the wind originates from coronal holes.

figures.short_title: Cross Helicity Concentrates Toward Unity in Fast Solar Wind Above 433 km/s

summary.what_we_see: This companion plot to Figure 3 displays normalized cross helicity (a measure of Alfvenicity, or how purely Alfvénic the solar wind turbulence is) as a function of solar wind speed using the same column-normalized 2D histogram format. The vertical axis now shows |σ_c| ranging from 0.0 (completely non-Alfvénic, no correlation between magnetic and velocity fluctuations) to 1.0 (purely Alfvénic, perfect correlation indicating undamped Alfvén waves), while the horizontal axis again spans 200-800 km/s. The color scheme is identical to Figure 3—each vertical speed column is normalized to its own maximum occurrence, with bright yellow indicating the most common |σ_c| value at that speed. The resulting pattern is dramatically different from helium abundance: in slow wind (200-400 km/s), the yellow band spans almost the entire vertical range from |σ_c| = 0 to 1.0, indicating slow wind exhibits all possible Alfvenicities from completely non-Alfvénic to purely Alfvénic with roughly equal likelihood. As speed increases, the yellow band progressively concentrates toward the top of the plot (high |σ_c|), forming a wedge shape that narrows toward |σ_c| ~ 1.0. A blue contour line traces the boundary enclosing 60% of observations in each speed column, intersecting the horizontal axis (|σ_c| = 0) at roughly 380 km/s—below this speed, observations span the full 0-1 range; above this speed, the lower edge of the 60% contour rises progressively, excluding low-|σ_c| values. Most critically, a vertical green line marks the helium saturation speed (v_s = 433 km/s) derived from Figure 3, with a shaded green band showing its ±4 km/s uncertainty. At this saturation speed, the blue 60% contour intersects at |σ_c| ≈ 0.7, meaning fast wind above 433 km/s is dominated by observations with cross helicity exceeding 0.7, while slow wind below 380 km/s includes substantial observations at all cross helicity values down to zero.
summary.the_finding: Cross helicity exhibits a progressive concentration toward unity (pure Alfvén wave character) as solar wind speed increases, but unlike helium abundance, which shows a sharp saturation at 433 km/s, the |σ_c| transition is gradual and begins at lower speeds. Below 380 km/s, the solar wind displays the full spectrum of Alfvenicities from |σ_c| = 0 (turbulent, non-Alfvénic) to |σ_c| = 1.0 (pristine Alfvénic), with no preferred value—this is evident from the vertical extent of the yellow band spanning the entire plot height. Between 380 and 600 km/s, the distribution progressively narrows: at each successively higher speed, the minimum |σ_c| value that still contributes substantially to the 60% contour increases, forming the wedge shape. By 600 km/s and beyond, the 60% contour has risen to |σ_c| ≈ 0.9, meaning nearly all fast wind observations are highly Alfvénic. Crucially, at the helium saturation speed of 433 km/s (vertical green line), the 60% contour sits at |σ_c| ≈ 0.7—this coincidence is not accidental but reveals that the speed where helium composition transitions from variable to saturated corresponds to where Alfvenicity begins to dominate (though full Alfvénic dominance extends to higher speeds). The fact that the 60% contour crosses zero at 380 km/s—about 50 km/s below the helium saturation speed—indicates cross helicity "leads" the compositional transition slightly, beginning its concentration toward high values before helium fully saturates. Unlike Figure 3's sharp helium transition (occurring over ~50 km/s around 433 km/s), the cross helicity transition is spread over ~220 km/s (from 380 where it begins to 600 where it completes), reflecting that Alfvenicity is set by wave generation and propagation processes between the sonic and Alfvén surfaces (per Figure 2) which can vary more gradually with source region properties than the chromospheric ionization processes that set helium abundance.
summary.why_it_matters: The progressive concentration of cross helicity toward unity in fast wind provides independent confirmation that high-speed solar wind originates from magnetically open coronal holes where Alfvén waves can propagate freely outward without reflection, while slow wind comes from complex closed-field regions where wave propagation is suppressed or waves propagate in both directions, reducing net correlation. The coincidence of the helium saturation speed (433 km/s, green line) with the cross helicity concentration zone (60% contour at |σ_c| ≈ 0.7 at 433 km/s) is the key observational evidence that these two completely independent plasma properties—one set in the chromosphere (helium, per Figure 2), the other set in the extended corona (cross helicity, per Figure 2)—both respond to the same underlying dichotomy in source region magnetic topology. This validates the paper's central premise that combining A_He and |σ_c| measurements creates a powerful two-dimensional classification scheme for mapping in situ observations back to source regions. The gradual nature of the |σ_c| transition (wedge narrowing over 220 km/s) versus the sharp helium transition (step function over ~50 km/s) suggests that while source regions divide into two discrete classes (open versus closed field), the properties of those classes vary along a continuum: coronal holes can have varying degrees of Alfvén wave activity depending on factors like hole size, magnetic field strength, and expansion geometry, producing a range of |σ_c| values from ~0.7 to 1.0 even within the "open field" population; whereas helium abundance, being set by chromospheric ionization, depends primarily on whether there's sufficient energy to ionize helium (yes in open field, no in closed field), producing a more binary outcome. The fact that slow wind (below 380 km/s) exhibits the full range of Alfvenicities including high values (|σ_c| approaching 1.0) is particularly important—it resolves the longstanding puzzle of "Alfvénic slow wind," plasma that is slow by speed standards (<400 km/s) yet highly Alfvénic by wave character (|σ_c| > 0.7). Prior studies struggled to explain this population because traditional models assumed slow wind from closed loops should be non-Alfvénic (low |σ_c|) due to wave damping in complex magnetic geometries. This figure shows such Alfvénic slow wind exists but is relatively rare (occupying only the upper-left corner of the speed-Alfvenicity plane), whereas the dominant slow wind population (the brightest yellow in slow wind columns) clusters at low to moderate |σ_c| around 0.2-0.5, consistent with closed-field expectations. The paper's later figures will reveal that this Alfvénic slow wind has distinct helium properties suggesting it originates from a specific subset of source regions—possibly the boundaries between open and closed field regions or recently opened flux emerging from decaying active regions. For spacecraft operations, the gradual |σ_c| transition means there's no single sharp Alfvenicity threshold analogous to the 433 km/s helium saturation speed—instead, |σ_c| > 0.7 serves as a probabilistic indicator of open-field origin, with confidence increasing as |σ_c| approaches unity. Combined with the helium threshold, this creates a two-parameter classification: wind with v > 433 km/s AND |σ_c| > 0.7 almost certainly originates from coronal holes, while wind with v < 433 km/s AND |σ_c| < 0.7 almost certainly originates from closed field regions, with intermediate cases requiring more careful analysis (addressed in Figures 10-11). The blue contour methodology—showing where 60% of observations fall at each speed—is more informative than traditional mean or median statistics because it reveals the shape of the distribution: symmetric (all Alfvenicities equally likely in slow wind) versus asymmetric (concentrated toward high Alfvenicity in fast wind), information that would be lost in a single summary statistic.

figures.short_title: Saturation Point Shifts Systematically with Cross Helicity Revealing Alfvenicity Dependence

summary.what_we_see: This complex multi-line plot reveals how the helium saturation behavior discovered in Figure 3 varies when you subdivide the data by Alfvenicity level, displayed as 15 overlapping two-piece linear fits color-coded by normalized cross helicity. The main panel uses the same axes as Figure 3—helium abundance (0-5%) versus solar wind speed (300-800 km/s)—but instead of a single pink fit line, it shows 15 separate fits (one for each of 15 quantiles dividing the |σ_c| range from 0 to 1 into equal-population bins). Line colors transition smoothly from deep blue (lowest Alfvenicity, |σ_c| ≈ 0-0.07) through cyan, green, yellow, orange, to deep red (highest Alfvenicity, |σ_c| ≈ 0.93-1.0), following the color bar legend. Each colored line exhibits the same two-piece linear character as Figure 3—a rising segment in slow wind followed by a flat segment in fast wind—but critically, the transition point (where the rising and flat segments meet, marked by green plus signs with error bars) shifts systematically with color: blue lines (low |σ_c|) have their saturation points at higher speeds (~430-435 km/s) and higher abundances (~4.1-4.2%), while red lines (high |σ_c|) have saturation points at lower speeds (~410-420 km/s) and lower abundances (~3.8-3.9%). An inset zoom panel in the upper left magnifies the 410-440 km/s speed range and 3.8-4.2% abundance range, providing a detailed view of how the 15 green saturation points (v_s, A_s) cluster in a diagonal band running from upper-right (low Alfvenicity: high speed, high abundance) to lower-left (high Alfvenicity: low speed, low abundance). The inset has the same aspect ratio as the main panel, ensuring the saturation points' diagonal trend is geometrically accurate. A gray diagonal guideline in the inset shows this anticorrelation visually. Additionally, all 15 colored lines share nearly identical slopes in their slow wind (rising) segments, converging toward a common x-intercept near 280-300 km/s, indicating the slow wind behavior (helium increasing with speed below saturation) is largely independent of Alfvenicity, whereas the fast wind segments (flat portions) are clearly separated vertically by color, indicating saturated helium abundance depends strongly on Alfvenicity.
summary.the_finding: Helium saturation speed (v_s) and saturation abundance (A_s) are strongly anticorrelated as a function of cross helicity (Alfvenicity): the most Alfvénic solar wind (|σ_c| approaching 1, red lines) saturates at the lowest speed (~410 km/s) and lowest abundance (~3.87%), while the least Alfvénic wind within the fast regime (|σ_c| ≈ 0.1-0.3, blue-cyan lines) saturates at the highest speed (~433 km/s) and highest abundance (~4.19%). The saturation speed shifts by roughly 25 km/s (410 to 435 km/s) across the Alfvenicity range, while saturation abundance shifts by about 0.3 percentage points (3.87% to 4.19%)—a modest absolute difference but representing an 8% relative change in the helium-to-hydrogen ratio. The anticorrelation forms a clean diagonal trend in the inset panel, indicating it's not random scatter but a systematic physical relationship: for every 0.1 increase in |σ_c|, the saturation speed decreases by roughly 2-3 km/s and saturation abundance decreases by roughly 0.03%. Crucially, while the saturation points shift, the character of the transition remains constant: all 15 fits show helium rising approximately linearly below their respective v_s values (parallel rising segments in the main panel, with slopes ranging only from ~0.030 to 0.040% per km/s despite spanning the full Alfvenicity range), then flattening abruptly to constant values above v_s (horizontal segments at different vertical positions corresponding to different A_s values). This parallel behavior in slow wind indicates that below ~400 km/s, helium abundance increases with speed at a rate that's largely insensitive to Alfvenicity—likely because both parameters are set by different physics in closed field regions, with helium controlled by chromospheric ionization and Alfvenicity by whatever limited wave activity exists in complex magnetic geometries. The systematic separation of the fast wind segments (horizontal colored lines stacked vertically) demonstrates that once helium saturates, its value depends strongly on Alfvenicity, with more Alfvénic wind carrying less helium—an initially counterintuitive result because highly Alfvénic wind from pristine coronal holes might be expected to carry more photospheric helium, not less.
summary.why_it_matters: The anticorrelation between saturation speed and saturation abundance as a function of Alfvenicity is the central discovery of this paper because it demonstrates that helium abundance and cross helicity are not independent classifiers but physically coupled by the acceleration mechanism, transforming them from two separate diagnostics into a two-dimensional phase space that uniquely fingerprints source regions. The fact that highly Alfvénic wind (red lines) saturates at lower helium abundance (~3.87% vs ~4.19%) challenges naive expectations and reveals subtle acceleration physics: in the most Alfvénic coronal holes (those with the strongest and most coherent outward-propagating Alfvén waves), helium is apparently accelerated less efficiently relative to hydrogen, perhaps because the wave energy couples preferentially to protons (hydrogen ions) whose cyclotron frequency better matches the wave spectrum, while the four-times-heavier helium ions resonate less efficiently and struggle to keep up. Alternatively, the most Alfvénic holes may be those with lower coronal temperatures (since higher temperatures would generate more turbulence, reducing Alfvenicity), and lower temperatures mean less helium is fully ionized in the chromosphere/transition region, reducing the available helium pool that can be accelerated. The lower saturation speed in high-|σ_c| wind (~410 km/s vs ~433 km/s) suggests that Alfvénic acceleration is so efficient that it brings the wind to its characteristic composition (saturated helium) at lower terminal speeds, whereas less Alfvénic holes require higher terminal speeds to achieve saturation, possibly because they compensate for weaker wave-driven acceleration with stronger thermal pressure gradients. The parallel rising segments below saturation (all colored lines climbing at ~0.035% per km/s regardless of color) confirm that the slow wind population—originating from closed field regions—has helium abundance controlled primarily by local source region properties (temperature, density, heating rate) rather than by Alfvén wave activity, consistent with Figure 2's cartoon showing A_He is set in the chromosphere before waves are generated. For practical classification of solar wind, this anticorrelation means you cannot simply use fixed thresholds (e.g., "saturated helium = open field"); instead, you must consider the (v_s, A_s) pair in context of the measured |σ_c|: wind at 420 km/s with 3.9% helium is saturated if |σ_c| ≈ 1.0 (red line) but not saturated if |σ_c| ≈ 0.2 (blue line), requiring the two-dimensional classification scheme developed in later figures. The inset panel's diagonal clustering of saturation points (green plus signs forming a lower-left to upper-right band) provides a clean empirical relationship that future theoretical models of solar wind acceleration must reproduce: any model that correctly captures chromospheric ionization, transition region heat flux, coronal wave generation, and Alfvénic acceleration should predict this exact anticorrelation, making it a stringent test of model physics. The modest error bars on the saturation points (visible in the inset) indicate this relationship is robust and not an artifact of statistical noise—each |σ_c| quantile contains thousands of measurements, providing tight constraints on v_s and A_s. The fact that the relationship is smooth rather than clustered suggests source regions vary continuously in their properties rather than dividing into discrete sub-classes, arguing against models that invoke qualitatively different acceleration mechanisms for different coronal hole types. For missions like Parker Solar Probe measuring solar wind much closer to the Sun, this anticorrelation predicts that helium abundance should still saturate but at different speeds depending on heliocentric distance (since the wind continues accelerating beyond 1 AU), and tracking how (v_s, A_s) evolves with distance will test whether saturation is set by local processes at the Alfvén surface or by chromospheric boundary conditions propagating outward.

figures.short_title: Rescaled Fits Collapse Onto Universal Curve Revealing Scale Invariance

summary.what_we_see: This elegant rescaling of Figure 5 tests whether the 15 different saturation curves (one per Alfvenicity quantile) are fundamentally the same shape, just shifted in position, by normalizing both axes to each curve's saturation point. The horizontal axis now shows v_sw/v_s (solar wind speed divided by that quantile's saturation speed), ranging from 0.5 to 2.0, while the vertical axis shows A_He/A_s (helium abundance divided by that quantile's saturation abundance), ranging from 0.0 to 1.4. With this rescaling, every saturation point from Figure 5's inset—which were scattered along a diagonal from (410 km/s, 3.87%) to (435 km/s, 4.19%)—now collapses to the single coordinate (1.0, 1.0), marked by a large green circle where all 15 fits intersect. The 15 colored lines maintain the same color scheme as Figure 5 (blue = low |σ_c| through red = high |σ_c|), but their behavior in this normalized space reveals profound structure: in the slow wind regime (v_sw/v_s < 1.0, left side of the plot), all 15 colored lines follow nearly identical steep diagonal paths from the origin (0, 0) to the saturation point (1.0, 1.0), forming a tight bundle that rises as a roughly linear ramp with slope close to 1.0, indicating A_He/A_s = v_sw/v_s in the sub-saturation regime. This remarkable collapse means that below saturation, helium increases toward its saturation value at the same normalized rate regardless of Alfvenicity. However, in the fast wind regime (v_sw/v_s > 1.0, right side of the plot), the 15 colored lines fan out horizontally from the saturation point (1.0, 1.0), with different colors reaching different maximum heights: blue lines (low |σ_c|) climb slightly to A_He/A_s ≈ 1.05-1.1 at the fastest speeds, indicating helium continues increasing weakly above the saturation point; orange and yellow lines (mid |σ_c|) remain essentially flat at A_He/A_s ≈ 1.0-1.05; while red lines (high |σ_c|) rise most strongly to A_He/A_s ≈ 1.2-1.4, indicating helium increases by 20-40% above its saturation value in the most Alfvénic fast wind. This fanning pattern is the opposite of the pre-saturation collapse: above saturation, helium behavior depends strongly on Alfvenicity.
summary.the_finding: The helium abundance saturation phenomenon exhibits scale invariance below the saturation point but breaks into Alfvenicity-dependent behavior above it, revealing two distinct physical regimes. In the sub-saturation regime (v_sw < v_s, or equivalently v_sw/v_s < 1.0), the collapse of all 15 colored lines onto a single trajectory demonstrates that helium rises from near-zero toward its saturation value following a universal scaling law: A_He/A_s ≈ v_sw/v_s, independent of Alfvenicity. This means if you measure solar wind at 90% of the saturation speed for a given Alfvenicity level, you'll find helium at approximately 90% of the saturation abundance for that level, regardless of whether you're in low-|σ_c| or high-|σ_c| wind. The tight bundling of all 15 lines in this regime (they overlap almost perfectly) indicates this scaling is robust, not an artifact of averaging. In the super-saturation regime (v_sw > v_s, or v_sw/v_s > 1.0), the fanning of colored lines reveals Alfvenicity-dependent physics: low-Alfvenicity wind (blue, |σ_c| ≈ 0.1) shows nearly perfect saturation—helium flatlines at A_He/A_s ≈ 1.0 out to the fastest speeds (v_sw/v_s ≈ 2.0, corresponding to ~870 km/s absolute speed), indicating true compositional saturation once the threshold is crossed. Mid-Alfvenicity wind (yellow-orange, |σ_c| ≈ 0.5-0.7) shows slight overshooting—helium rises to ~5-10% above the saturation value at the highest speeds. High-Alfvenicity wind (red, |σ_c| ≈ 0.9-1.0) shows strong overshooting—helium reaches 20-40% above saturation at the fastest speeds, with the deepest red line climbing to A_He/A_s ≈ 1.4 at v_sw/v_s ≈ 2.0. Converting back to absolute units, this high-|σ_c| overshooting means helium can reach ~5.4% (1.4 × 3.87% saturation value for high-|σ_c| wind) at speeds around 820 km/s (2.0 × 410 km/s saturation speed), substantially higher than the 3.87% saturation value but still well below the 8.5% photospheric abundance. The transition from collapse (perfect overlap below saturation) to fanning (Alfvenicity-dependent spreading above saturation) occurs sharply at v_sw/v_s = 1.0, with no intermediate regime.
summary.why_it_matters: The scale-invariant collapse below saturation and Alfvenicity-dependent fanning above saturation reveal that solar wind acceleration involves two sequential stages with fundamentally different physics, transforming our understanding of how composition couples to dynamics. The sub-saturation collapse (all lines bundled) demonstrates that helium abundance in closed-field and mixed-source slow wind is controlled by a universal process that depends only on how close the wind has approached its final speed relative to its saturation threshold, not on the magnetic topology or wave activity that varies with Alfvenicity. This universal scaling likely reflects chromospheric ionization and transition region physics: as heating increases (driving higher terminal speeds), helium ionization efficiency increases proportionally, liberating more helium ions that can be accelerated, but the relationship between ionization and speed is set by fundamental atomic physics (helium's 24.6 eV ionization potential) and radiative transfer, producing the same normalized curve regardless of source region Alfvenicity. The sharp break at the saturation point (v_sw/v_s = 1.0, where universal collapse transitions to Alfvenicity-dependent fanning) indicates a qualitative change in acceleration mechanism—likely the transition from predominantly closed-field or mixed-source regions (where thermal pressure and reconnection dominate, controlling both speed and composition) to predominantly open-field coronal holes (where Alfvén wave pressure provides additional acceleration beyond what chromospheric ionization alone would support). The fanning above saturation—particularly the strong helium overshooting in high-|σ_c| wind (red lines reaching A_He/A_s ≈ 1.4)—resolves an apparent paradox from Figure 5: highly Alfvénic wind has lower saturation abundance (A_s ≈ 3.87%) but at the fastest absolute speeds (~800 km/s), it actually carries more helium (~5.4%) than low-Alfvenicity wind at the same speed (~4.2%), because it overshoots its lower saturation value by a larger factor. This suggests that Alfvén waves, while less efficient at ionizing helium in the chromosphere (producing lower A_s), are highly efficient at continuing to accelerate whatever helium is present once the wind exceeds the saturation speed, perhaps because Alfvén waves couple more strongly to helium ions in super-Alfvénic flow than in sub-Alfvénic flow where thermal processes dominate. The fact that low-Alfvenicity wind (blue lines) shows almost no overshooting (perfect flatline at A_He/A_s ≈ 1.0) confirms these are genuinely saturated—helium has reached its maximum abundance for the given source region conditions and cannot increase further regardless of speed, consistent with a scenario where chromospheric ionization provides a fixed helium reservoir that gets depleted but cannot be replenished once the wind disconnects from the Sun. For theoretical models, the universal sub-saturation scaling (A_He/A_s ≈ v_sw/v_s) provides a stringent quantitative target: models must produce this exact 1:1 proportionality between normalized abundance and normalized speed for all source region types, implying a tight coupling between whatever sets terminal speed (coronal heating, magnetic expansion geometry) and whatever sets helium ionization (chromospheric temperature, UV radiation field). The Alfvenicity-dependent fanning above saturation requires models to include Alfvén wave effects on helium acceleration specifically in super-critical flow, not just hydrogen acceleration. For practical solar wind classification, this figure demonstrates you cannot rescale away the Alfvenicity dependence—there's no single "master curve" that describes all solar wind, only a master curve below saturation followed by Alfvenicity-specific behavior above saturation, necessitating the two-dimensional (A_He, |σ_c|) classification scheme developed in Figures 10-11. The overshooting in high-|σ_c| wind also explains why simple speed-based thresholds (like "fast wind = v > 500 km/s") perform poorly for composition classification—even within the fast wind population, helium varies by a factor of 1.4 (from saturation to overshoot) depending on Alfvenicity, creating substantial overlap with the upper end of the slow wind compositional range.

figures.short_title: Saturation Speed Decreases and Saturation Abundance Increases with Cross Helicity

summary.what_we_see: This two-panel figure quantifies the systematic trends glimpsed in Figure 5's inset by plotting how saturation speed and saturation abundance vary across the full Alfvenicity range. Panel (a) shows saturation speed v_s (vertical axis, 410-440 km/s) versus normalized cross helicity |σ_c| (horizontal axis, 0.0-1.0), with 15 colored circles representing the 15 Alfvenicity quantiles—colors transition from blue (|σ_c| ≈ 0) through cyan, green, yellow, orange to red (|σ_c| ≈ 1.0) matching earlier figures. Each circle has vertical error bars indicating fitting uncertainty. The circles trace a clear downward trend from upper-left (v_s ≈ 433 km/s at |σ_c| ≈ 0.05) to lower-right (v_s ≈ 410 km/s at |σ_c| ≈ 0.98), with a black dotted line connecting them to guide the eye. A horizontal pink line with pink shaded band marks the saturation speed (433 km/s) and its uncertainty (±4 km/s) derived from the all-data fit in Figure 3, showing how the quantile-specific values scatter around this global average. Three horizontal cyan lines with cyan shaded regions mark weighted mean values for three broad Alfvenicity ranges: "Low" (|σ_c| = 0-0.33, v_s = 430 km/s), "Mid" (|σ_c| = 0.33-0.67, v_s = 420 km/s), and "High" (|σ_c| = 0.67-1.0, v_s = 410 km/s). Panel (b) uses identical formatting but plots saturation abundance A_s (vertical axis, 3.7-4.3%) versus |σ_c|, showing the opposite trend: circles rise from lower-left (A_s ≈ 3.87% at |σ_c| ≈ 0.98) to upper-right (A_s ≈ 4.19% at |σ_c| ≈ 0.05). The same pink reference line and cyan range averages appear, now showing A_s = 4.19% for all data, and A_s = 3.87%, 4.01%, and 4.13% for High, Mid, and Low |σ_c| ranges respectively.
summary.the_finding: Saturation speed and saturation abundance exhibit strong, monotonic, opposite trends with Alfvenicity across the full |σ_c| range from 0 to 1, confirming and quantifying the diagonal pattern observed in Figure 5's inset. As normalized cross helicity increases from 0 to 1.0 (moving left to right on the horizontal axis), saturation speed decreases systematically by 23 km/s from 433 km/s to 410 km/s—a 5% drop (panel a)—while saturation abundance decreases simultaneously by 0.32 percentage points from 4.19% to 3.87%—an 8% drop (panel b). The trends are remarkably linear: a simple straight line fit would capture most of the variation, with saturation speed dropping by roughly 23 km/s per unit |σ_c| and saturation abundance dropping by roughly 0.32% per unit |σ_c|. The three-range averages (cyan lines) demonstrate that even crudely binning Alfvenicity into thirds captures the essential trend: Low-|σ_c| wind saturates at (430 km/s, 4.13%), Mid-|σ_c| at (420 km/s, 4.01%), and High-|σ_c| at (410 km/s, 3.87%), with each step down in speed accompanied by a step down in abundance. The error bars on individual quantiles (vertical lines on colored circles) are generally small (±2-5 km/s for speed, ±0.05-0.10% for abundance), much smaller than the total variation across the |σ_c| range, confirming these are robust trends rather than statistical scatter. Notably, the all-data reference values (pink lines: 433 km/s, 4.19%) sit at the upper end of the quantile range, closer to the low-|σ_c| values than the high-|σ_c| values, indicating the all-data average is dominated by low-to-mid Alfvenicity wind rather than being an unweighted average—this makes physical sense because Figure 4 showed low-|σ_c| wind is more common than high-|σ_c| wind at speeds around 400-500 km/s, so the all-data fit is skewed toward the more populous low-Alfvenicity regime. The smooth monotonic trends (no plateaus or reversals) indicate this is a fundamental continuous relationship rather than discrete source region classes, though the three-range binning shows practical classification can still use coarse Alfvenicity categories.
summary.why_it_matters: These opposite monotonic trends—saturation speed decreasing while saturation abundance also decreases with rising Alfvenicity—crystallize the paper's central physical insight: highly Alfvénic coronal holes accelerate solar wind to saturation conditions at lower speeds but with less helium, while weakly Alfvénic holes require higher speeds to saturate but carry more helium, implying fundamentally different energetics governing wave-driven versus thermally-driven acceleration. The anticorrelation is counterintuitive because naive reasoning suggests "more efficient acceleration" (high Alfvenicity) should both increase speed and preserve composition, producing high v_s and high A_s; instead, high Alfvenicity produces low v_s and low A_s, indicating wave-driven acceleration is compositionally selective—highly efficient at accelerating hydrogen but less efficient at ionizing or accelerating helium. The physical mechanism likely involves the altitude where helium ionization occurs (chromosphere, per Figure 2): in low-Alfvenicity holes with stronger thermal pressure gradients, higher chromospheric temperatures fully ionize more helium, producing high A_s, but the lack of wave activity means the wind must rely on thermal expansion to reach high speeds, only achieving saturation at higher v_s; in high-Alfvenicity holes with strong Alfvén waves but lower thermal pressure, cooler chromospheric temperatures ionize less helium, producing low A_s, but efficient wave-driven acceleration saturates the composition at lower v_s because waves couple strongly to hydrogen (which is already ionized) rather than neutral helium (which isn't). The 23 km/s variation in v_s across the |σ_c| range (410-433 km/s) is substantial—it spans the same range as the width of the transition zone between slow and fast wind in Figure 1, indicating Alfvenicity is as important as source region type (open vs closed field) in determining at what speed compositional saturation occurs. The 0.32% variation in A_s (3.87-4.19%) represents 8% relative variation in helium abundance, comparable to the difference between some coronal hole and active region measurements, demonstrating that even within the open-field population, composition varies systematically with wave activity. For theoretical modeling, these linear trends provide exact quantitative targets: models must reproduce d(v_s)/d(|σ_c|) ≈ -23 km/s and d(A_s)/d(|σ_c|) ≈ -0.32%, requiring precise balancing of chromospheric ionization, transition region heat flux, and coronal wave-particle interactions. The fact that both quantities vary linearly (rather than exponentially or with plateaus) suggests the underlying physics involves continuous tuning of a single parameter—likely the ratio of wave energy to thermal energy in the coronal hole—rather than switching between qualitatively different regimes. The three-range binning (Low/Mid/High |σ_c|) demonstrates practical utility: even without measuring the full |σ_c| distribution, missions can classify wind into three compositional categories with distinct v_s and A_s values differing by ~10 km/s and ~0.13%, enabling meaningful source region discrimination without requiring high-precision |σ_c| measurements. The fact that all-data values (pink lines) fall near the low-|σ_c| end reveals a selection bias in typical solar wind datasets: at speeds around 400-450 km/s where saturation occurs, low-to-mid Alfvenicity wind dominates the observations (per Figure 4's wedge pattern), meaning studies that don't subdivide by Alfvenicity are effectively measuring low-|σ_c| saturation conditions (v_s ≈ 430-433 km/s, A_s ≈ 4.13-4.19%) and missing the high-|σ_c| regime (v_s ≈ 410 km/s, A_s ≈ 3.87%) that represents the purest coronal hole wind. For space weather forecasting, these trends enable refined predictions: measuring |σ_c| ≈ 0.9 indicates wind that will saturate at 412 km/s with 3.90% helium (interpolating panel curves), whereas measuring |σ_c| ≈ 0.3 indicates saturation at 428 km/s with 4.10% helium, allowing forecasters to anticipate compositional properties from wave measurements alone. The small error bars validate that future missions can confidently use these relationships—the trends are robust across the 28-year dataset, not fragile correlations that might disappear with different sampling or solar cycle phases.

figures.short_title: Helium Number Density Peaks at Saturation Speed Revealing Physical Transition

summary.what_we_see: This logarithmically-scaled plot reveals how the absolute number density (particles per cubic centimeter) of hydrogen and helium varies with solar wind speed, providing a complementary perspective to the abundance ratios examined in previous figures. The vertical axis uses logarithmic scale from 0.1 to 10 particles/cm³, while the horizontal axis spans 300-800 km/s. Two curves dominate: a solid green line shows hydrogen (proton) number density n_H starting high (~10 cm⁻³) at slow speeds and decreasing monotonically to ~2-3 cm⁻³ at fast speeds, with a semitransparent green shaded band indicating ±1 standard deviation scatter; a dashed orange line shows helium (alpha particle) number density n_He following a dramatically different pattern—rising from ~0.12 cm⁻³ at 300 km/s to a distinct peak of ~0.22 cm⁻³ near 400-450 km/s, then declining to ~0.12 cm⁻³ at 700+ km/s, forming a clear "hump" shape with maximum near the transition from slow to fast wind. The orange shaded band around the helium curve is proportionally wider than the hydrogen band, indicating greater variability. Five colored vertical bands highlight critical speeds: a purple band near 355 km/s marks v_slow (the slow wind peak from Figure 1); an orange band near 410 km/s marks v_n (the helium density peak); a cyan band spanning ~407-439 km/s marks the range of saturation speeds v_s across different Alfvenicities (from Figure 7); a green band near 484 km/s marks v_i (where slow and fast wind Gaussians intersect from Figure 1); and a purple band near 622 km/s marks v_fast (the fast wind peak). The helium density peak (orange band, v_n) sits squarely within the saturation speed range (cyan band), demonstrating their coincidence.
summary.the_finding: Helium number density peaks precisely at the saturation speed (~410-440 km/s depending on Alfvenicity), reaching a maximum of approximately 0.22 cm⁻³—roughly 80% higher than values at either slower (~300 km/s, where n_He ≈ 0.12 cm⁻³) or faster speeds (>600 km/s, where n_He again ≈ 0.12 cm⁻³). This peak location at v_n ≈ 409±15 km/s (orange band) coincides almost exactly with the saturation speed v_s range (407-439 km/s, cyan band) derived from composition analysis, despite these being completely independent measurements—density versus abundance ratio. The peak is not subtle; it stands out clearly above both the slow wind and fast wind density values, forming a genuine local maximum rather than a plateau or shoulder. Meanwhile, hydrogen density declines monotonically and smoothly from ~10 cm⁻³ in slow wind to ~2-3 cm⁻³ in fast wind, showing no peak or inflection at the saturation speed—the hydrogen curve is a simple power law n_H ∝ v_sw^(-2) or similar, consistent with Parker solar wind model expectations where faster wind from larger source regions carries lower density due to flux conservation. The ratio of helium to hydrogen density at the peak (~0.22/~4 ≈ 5.5%) exceeds the saturation abundance derived from abundance ratio measurements (4.19%), indicating the helium density peak actually represents a transition zone where helium abundance slightly overshoots its saturation value before settling to the constant fast-wind level—an effect masked in Figure 3's abundance analysis by the ±1σ spread but revealed here by examining absolute densities. The width of the helium peak (full width at half maximum ~100 km/s, spanning roughly 360-460 km/s) encompasses the entire transition zone from slow wind peak (v_slow = 355 km/s) through saturation speed range (v_s = 407-439 km/s) to just below the slow-fast intersection (v_i = 484 km/s), indicating this is the critical speed range where compositional physics transitions from variable/rising to saturated/constant.
summary.why_it_matters: The helium density peak at the saturation speed provides smoking-gun evidence that this speed represents a genuine physical transition in solar wind source regions and acceleration mechanisms, not merely a statistical artifact of how we fit abundance curves. If saturation were just a mathematical convenience (e.g., fitting error causing an apparent flattening), there would be no reason for an independent quantity like number density—which depends on source region flux, coronal expansion, and geometric dilution during propagation—to show special behavior at the same speed. Instead, the coincidence of the abundance saturation (v_s from Figure 3) and the density maximum (v_n from this figure) reveals that at ~410-440 km/s, the solar wind undergoes a fundamental transition where both the compositional properties (helium-to-hydrogen ratio) and the absolute flux of helium change character. The physical interpretation is profound: the helium density peak marks the boundary between two populations—slow wind from magnetically closed or mixed-source regions (below v_n), where helium abundance is rising but total helium flux remains low due to limited ionization, and fast wind from magnetically open coronal holes (above v_n), where helium abundance has saturated but total helium flux begins declining because fast wind from larger coronal holes carries intrinsically lower densities due to flux tube expansion geometry. At the peak itself (~410-440 km/s), we're sampling a transition zone—likely the boundaries of coronal holes or recently-opened flux at the edges of active regions—where helium ionization has just reached its maximum efficiency (producing high A_He and high n_He simultaneously) but the source regions haven't yet achieved the large-scale expansion geometry of pure coronal holes (which would reduce density). The fact that hydrogen shows no corresponding peak—just monotonic decline with speed—demonstrates this is helium-specific physics, tied to helium's unique ionization properties (requiring higher temperatures than hydrogen, per the 24.6 eV ionization potential) rather than a generic property of solar wind acceleration. The coincidence of v_n with the saturation speed range v_s validates the two-piece linear fit methodology from Figure 3: if the fit were forcing an artificial transition, the density peak would occur at a different speed, but instead they align within ~5 km/s, confirming the transition is real. For understanding coronal hole structure, the helium density peak suggests holes have compositionally distinct boundaries—a narrow "transition layer" at ~410-440 km/s where both abundance and density maximize before settling into the pure fast wind regime at >500 km/s. Future high-resolution coronal imaging should look for morphological features at the boundaries of coronal holes that correlate with this compositional transition zone. The peak width (~100 km/s) provides a measure of the "fuzziness" of the closed-to-open field boundary: if source regions switched abruptly between closed and open at a single well-defined surface, the peak would be much narrower (limited only by solar wind variability), but the ~100 km/s width indicates a gradual transition involving mixed connectivity or time-variable opening/closing. For space weather forecasting, the helium density peak provides an observable threshold: when spacecraft measure rising helium density approaching 0.20-0.22 cm⁻³, forecasters know the wind is transitioning from slow/closed-field to fast/open-field source regions, enabling predictions that a fast wind stream will arrive within hours (the time for wind to transit from current location to Earth). Missions planning to sample coronal holes should target speed ranges around v_n (400-450 km/s) to capture the maximum helium flux, optimizing composition measurements. The comparison of highlighted speeds (purple, orange, cyan, green bands) demonstrates how multiple independent classification schemes converge: v_slow (355 km/s) marks the slow wind peak, v_n (409 km/s) marks the helium density peak, v_s (407-439 km/s) marks the compositional saturation, and v_i (484 km/s) marks the slow-fast intersection—these four speeds span just 129 km/s yet represent qualitatively different transitions (speed distribution, density, abundance, population mixing), showing the 350-500 km/s range is a rich "transition zone" rather than a simple boundary.

figures.short_title: Five Critical Speeds Subdivide Bimodal Distribution into Physical Regimes

summary.what_we_see: This annotated version of Figure 1's solar minimum speed distribution transforms a simple probability curve into a physically segmented classification scheme by overlaying five colored speed ranges derived from independent analyses. The familiar solid black curve shows the bimodal solar wind speed distribution during solar minima (probability density on logarithmic vertical axis from 10⁻⁵ to 10⁻² versus speed from 300-800 km/s on horizontal axis), with its characteristic dual peaks at ~355 km/s (slow wind) and ~622 km/s (fast wind) separated by a valley around 484 km/s. Five vertical colored bands now subdivide this distribution: (1) Purple shading centered on 355 km/s with width ±44 km/s (spanning ~311-399 km/s) marks v_slow, the slow wind peak; (2) Orange shading near 410 km/s marks v_n, the helium density peak from Figure 8; (3) Cyan shading spanning approximately 407-439 km/s marks the range of saturation speeds v_s across Alfvenicities from Figure 7; (4) Green shading centered on 484 km/s marks v_i, where slow and fast wind Gaussians intersect; (5) Purple shading centered on 622 km/s with width ±58 km/s (spanning ~564-680 km/s) marks v_fast, the fast wind peak. The colored bands divide the probability curve into distinct regions: the leftmost purple band captures the peak of the slow wind hump; the orange and cyan bands (partially overlapping) straddle the transition zone where the slow wind hump gives way to the valley; the green band sits at the deepest part of the valley; and the rightmost purple band captures the fast wind hump. Critically, the cyan saturation speed range (v_s) sits just on the slow-wind side of the valley, while the green intersection speed (v_i) sits in the valley's center, demonstrating that compositional saturation (cyan) occurs ~30-50 km/s before the slow-fast boundary traditionally defined by speed distribution (green).
summary.the_finding: The five independently-derived critical speeds—v_slow (355 km/s, slow wind peak), v_n (409 km/s, helium density peak), v_s (407-439 km/s, saturation speed range), v_i (484 km/s, slow-fast intersection), and v_fast (622 km/s, fast wind peak)—subdivide the bimodal solar minimum speed distribution into physically meaningful regimes that align with, but don't exactly match, the traditional slow/fast dichotomy. The slow wind peak (leftmost purple) sits squarely in the high-probability region of the slow wind hump, confirming it represents the "typical" slow wind most commonly observed. The saturation speed range (cyan, 407-439 km/s) spans the right shoulder of the slow wind hump and the beginning of the inter-peak valley, occurring at speeds where probability has dropped to ~50% of the slow wind peak maximum—this placement demonstrates compositional saturation happens while the solar wind is still predominantly slow-wind-like in its speed characteristics, not after it has fully transitioned to fast wind. The helium density peak (orange, 409 km/s) sits at nearly the same location as the low end of the saturation speed range, confirming their physical connection (both mark the closed-to-open field transition). The slow-fast intersection speed (green, 484 km/s) falls in the deepest part of the valley between the two humps, at the point where probability has dropped to ~0.001 (one-tenth of one percent)—speeds in this green band are genuinely rare during solar minimum, observed only ~0.1% of the time, indicating this is a "forbidden zone" where neither typical slow wind mechanisms nor typical fast wind mechanisms operate efficiently. The fast wind peak (rightmost purple, 622 km/s) sits at the maximum of the fast wind hump, representing the canonical coronal hole fast wind. The spacing between these critical speeds is highly uneven: v_slow to v_s spans 52-84 km/s, v_s to v_i spans 45-77 km/s, but v_i to v_fast spans 138 km/s, showing the fast wind regime is broader in speed space than the slow wind regime. The overlap and near-coincidence of v_n (orange) and v_s (cyan)—they differ by at most ~10 km/s—demonstrates these represent the same physical transition viewed through different observables (density versus abundance ratio), while the larger separation of v_s and v_i (~45-77 km/s) shows compositional transitions lead kinematic transitions.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure synthesizes the paper's central message: traditional slow/fast wind classification based solely on speed (using v_i = 484 km/s or similar thresholds) misses critical compositional physics occurring 50-80 km/s slower, and a proper classification requires recognizing at least three—not two—distinct speed regimes during solar minimum. The first regime (speeds below v_s ≈ 410-430 km/s, covering the purple slow wind peak and its right shoulder) represents genuine closed-field or mixed-source slow wind where helium abundance is variable and sub-saturated, source regions have complex topology, and Alfvenicity spans the full range from 0 to 1; this regime contains the vast majority of slow wind observations (the tall purple peak). The second regime (speeds between v_s ≈ 410-430 km/s and v_i = 484 km/s, spanning the cyan saturation band through the green intersection) represents a compositional transition zone where helium has saturated (indicating open-field character) but speed remains intermediate, suggesting these are coronal hole boundary regions, small/nascent holes, or holes with weak expansion factors that don't accelerate to typical fast wind speeds; this regime is rare (the valley between peaks) but physically important as it proves composition and speed are partially decoupled. The third regime (speeds above v_i = 484 km/s, covering the green intersection band and purple fast wind peak) represents mature open-field coronal hole wind where both composition (saturated helium) and speed (>500 km/s) indicate efficient acceleration, with Alfvenicity concentrated toward high values; this regime bifurcates into intermediate speeds (484-564 km/s, where slow wind "contamination" still occurs per the paper's discussion) and pure fast wind (>564 km/s, the purple fast wind peak band, where origin is exclusively open field). The early saturation (cyan at 410-430 km/s) relative to the traditional slow/fast boundary (green at 484 km/s) is the discovery's operational significance: spacecraft measuring composition can identify the closed-to-open field transition 50-80 km/s sooner (and thus ~3-6 hours earlier at 1 AU) than spacecraft measuring only speed, enabling earlier space weather warnings when fast wind streams are approaching. The rarity of the transition zone (green band showing probability ~0.001, three orders of magnitude below the slow wind peak's ~0.01) explains why previous studies missed it—most statistical analyses of solar wind either focus on the peaks (where data are plentiful) or simply divide the distribution at some fixed threshold (like 400 or 500 km/s), both approaches that skip over the physically rich but data-sparse valley region where compositional transitions occur. For coronal physics, the placement of saturation speeds (cyan) at the slow wind hump's right shoulder rather than at the valley's center suggests the magnetic topology transition (closed to open field) is sharper than the speed transition, with composition changing abruptly over ~30 km/s (width of cyan band) while speed changes gradually over ~130 km/s (distance from cyan to purple fast wind peak). The coincidence of v_n (orange) and v_s (cyan) validates that helium density and abundance transitions are causally linked—both reflect the same underlying change in chromospheric ionization efficiency and coronal expansion geometry at the boundaries of coronal holes. The large gap between v_i (green, 484 km/s) and v_fast (purple, 622 km/s)—138 km/s—shows that even within the "fast wind" population (speeds above the slow-fast intersection), there's substantial variation requiring further subdivision; the paper's discussion notes that speeds from 484-564 km/s still show slow wind contamination, with pure open-field wind only dominating above 564 km/s (upper edge of the rightmost purple band). For future missions, this figure provides concrete operational speed ranges: sample below 410 km/s to study closed-field slow wind, sample 410-440 km/s to study the compositional transition zone, sample 440-564 km/s to study mixed open/closed populations, and sample above 564 km/s to study pure coronal hole wind. The annotated distribution also reveals what's missing—there are no critical speeds identified in the 440-484 km/s range (between cyan and green bands), suggesting this is a "dead zone" where neither slow wind peaks nor compositional transitions nor fast wind acceleration produces distinctive features, consistent with it being a simple geometric mixing region where open and closed field winds co-exist without unique physics.

figures.short_title: Two-Dimensional Classification Reveals Distinct Closed and Open Field Populations

summary.what_we_see:
This three-panel figure presents the paper's culminating visualization: solar wind speed mapped onto the two-dimensional plane of cross helicity and helium abundance. Each panel shows the same axes with overlaid contours but colors the heatmap by different statistical summaries.

Panel (a) uses mean solar wind speed, spanning 300-540 km/s. Two distinct populations emerge: a crescent-shaped region in the lower-left colored blue-green (320-420 km/s) representing slow wind from closed fields, and a wedge-shaped region in the upper-right colored orange-red (460-520 km/s) representing fast wind from open fields. Six labeled contour lines mark critical speeds from previous figures.

Panel (b) shows the 10th percentile of speed. The entire plane is colored blue-green with speeds below 420 km/s, indicating slow wind contaminates almost the entire plane at least 10% of the time. Panel (c) shows the 90th percentile. The upper-right wedge reaches 600-690 km/s, while the lower-left region stays below 500 km/s.
summary.the_finding:
The cross-helicity and helium-abundance plane cleanly separates solar wind into two populations with a diagonal boundary. Closed-field slow wind occupies the region with cross helicity below 0.5 and helium below 4%. Mean speeds range 320-420 km/s. Open-field fast wind occupies the region with cross helicity above 0.7 and helium above 3.5%. Mean speeds range 460-540 km/s.

The separation is not perfect. A substantial diagonal mixing zone spans cross helicity 0.4-0.8 and helium 3-5%. Mean speeds here are intermediate at 420-480 km/s. This region samples both populations or genuinely transitional source regions.

The critical speed contours align with population separation. The saturation speed contours trace the boundary between closed and open field populations. The 10th versus 90th percentile comparison reveals critical population overlap. Even high-Alfvenicity, high-helium regions show a 10% chance of slow wind speeds.
summary.why_it_matters:
This two-dimensional classification solves the longstanding problem of Alfvenic slow wind. It provides a composition-based alternative to speed-only classification without requiring full charge-state measurements.

Traditional speed-only classification misclassifies a substantial fraction of solar wind. Panel (a) shows regions with mean speed 420-480 km/s spanning cross helicity from 0.3 to 0.9. These intermediate speeds sample fundamentally different source regions depending on Alfvenicity and composition.

The low-Alfvenicity, low-helium portion at these speeds represents closed-field slow wind that happens to be unusually fast. Such wind may come from active region boundaries. The high-Alfvenicity, mid-helium portion represents open-field fast wind that happens to be unusually slow. This may come from small or equatorial coronal holes with weak expansion.

By adding composition and wave dimensions, classification becomes robust. Anything in the lower-left quadrant is closed-field regardless of speed. Anything in the upper-right wedge is open-field regardless of speed. This resolves ambiguities that plague speed-only schemes.

For practical operations, spacecraft need only a Faraday cup for speed and density plus a magnetometer for cross helicity. These instruments are standard on almost all heliospheric missions. Traditional composition-based classification requires expensive mass spectrometers, making this scheme far more accessible.

figures.short_title: Cartoon Classification Scheme Maps Four Populations in Composition-Wave Space

summary.what_we_see: This interpretive cartoon simplifies Figure 10's quantitative heatmap into a qualitative classification scheme with four clearly labeled regions on the (|σ_c|, A_He) plane. The axes remain identical—normalized cross helicity (0 to 1.0 horizontally) and helium abundance (0 to 10% vertically)—but instead of color-coded speeds, the plane is divided into four discrete zones by thick black boundary contours drawn at v_sw = 425 km/s and 460 km/s (marked as black contour lines with labels). The lower portion of the plane (roughly A_He < 4%, |σ_c| < 0.6) is colored pale green and labeled in large bold text "Closed Field", indicating solar wind likely originating from magnetically closed loop structures. The right side (roughly A_He > 3%, |σ_c| > 0.8) is colored pink-red and labeled "Open Field", indicating solar wind likely from coronal holes. The upper-left corner (high A_He > 8%, low-to-mid |σ_c| < 0.7) is colored darker red and labeled "Transients", indicating coronal mass ejections. The central diagonal region (roughly A_He ≈ 3-7%, |σ_c| ≈ 0.4-0.8) is colored orange-tan and labeled "Mixed Source", indicating wind from boundaries, mixed connectivity, or transitional regions. A diagonal arrow within the Mixed Source region points toward the upper-right (toward the Open Field boundary) with text "More Open", suggesting a continuous gradient rather than a sharp transition. A gray-shaded diagonal band spanning roughly |σ_c| ≈ 0.7-0.9 and A_He ≈ 3-5% is overlaid with text "v_s" and a note indicating this gray region marks the saturation speed range, with text explaining "the exact v_sw at which this transition happens likely depends on the solar wind sample under consideration"—the graying-out visually de-emphasizes this band to indicate it's a fuzzy boundary rather than a sharp line.
summary.the_finding: The (|σ_c|, A_He) plane divides naturally into four populations, though the boundaries are gradual rather than sharp: (1) Closed Field (lower-left, green): |σ_c| < ~0.5 and A_He < ~4%, representing slow wind from magnetically closed loops, helmet streamers, and active region boundaries—this is the dominant slow wind population with highly variable composition and low-to-moderate Alfvenicity; (2) Open Field (right, pink): |σ_c| > ~0.7 and A_He > ~3%, representing fast wind from coronal holes—this population has saturated helium abundance (A_He clustering around 4-5% depending on |σ_c|, per Figure 7's anticorrelation) and high Alfvenicity from coherent outward-propagating waves; (3) Mixed Source (center diagonal, orange): intermediate |σ_c| ≈ 0.4-0.8 and A_He ≈ 3-7%, representing transition regions, coronal hole boundaries, or time-variable connectivity—the arrow labeled "More Open" indicates a continuous gradient from closed-field-like (lower-left side of this region) to open-field-like (upper-right side) rather than a homogeneous mixing; (4) Transients (upper-left, dark red): high A_He > ~8% with low-to-mid |σ_c| < 0.7, representing coronal mass ejections which carry enhanced helium (often >10%) but lack organized Alfvénic structure due to turbulent compression and expansion. The gray v_s band (saturation speed range) runs diagonally through the Mixed Source region, marking where helium abundance transitions from variable to saturated, with the graying and annotation emphasizing this is a probabilistic boundary that depends on solar cycle phase, sampling period, and Alfvenicity level rather than a fixed threshold. The boundaries between regions are drawn as smooth curves rather than straight lines, indicating they're empirically derived from data structure (the contours in Figure 10) rather than theoretically imposed. The lack of a "Forbidden" or "Empty" region indicates all combinations of |σ_c| and A_He are observed, though with vastly different frequencies (Closed Field and Open Field being most common, Mixed Source and Transients being rarer).
summary.why_it_matters: This cartoon provides the paper's operational deliverable: a simple, interpretable classification scheme that any heliospheric mission can use to identify solar wind source regions from two readily-measurable plasma properties, enabling source region mapping without expensive charge-state composition instruments or complex modeling. The four-population scheme (Closed/Open/Mixed/Transients) is more nuanced than the traditional two-population dichotomy (slow/fast) and captures physical distinctions that matter for space weather forecasting: Closed Field wind brings embedded flux ropes and slow-stream density enhancements that can trigger moderate geomagnetic activity; Open Field wind brings sustained high-speed streams that drive recurrent storms with ~27-day periodicity; Mixed Source wind is unpredictable, sometimes behaving like slow wind and sometimes like fast wind depending on whether the closed or open component dominates at the moment of measurement; Transients bring extreme densities, strong magnetic fields, and embedded shocks that cause the most severe geomagnetic storms and are easily distinguished from steady wind by their extreme helium enhancement. The diagonal orientation of the boundaries (running lower-left to upper-right) encodes the paper's central physical insight: composition (A_He) and wave activity (|σ_c|) are anticorrelated in open-field wind (per Figure 7)—the most Alfvénic coronal holes carry less helium—so the Open Field region is a diagonal wedge rather than a rectangular corner of the plot. The "More Open" arrow within the Mixed Source region acknowledges that this isn't a distinct source region type but rather a superposition or transition zone, with properties shifting continuously from closed-field-dominated (lower-left edge) to open-field-dominated (upper-right edge) depending on the local ratio of closed to open flux in the photospheric source region. The grayed-out v_s band emphasizes an important subtlety: the saturation speed is not a sharp physical boundary but a statistical property that varies with Alfvenicity (410-439 km/s range from Figure 7) and possibly with solar cycle phase, sampling technique, and instrumental resolution—the graying visually warns users not to over-interpret this boundary as a fundamental dividing line. For practical implementation, the cartoon enables real-time classification: spacecraft at L1 measures |σ_c| = 0.3 and A_He = 2.5% → lookup on this diagram → Closed Field → expect slow, variable wind, likely from helmet streamer, possible embedded transient structures, low space weather impact unless CME present. Alternatively, |σ_c| = 0.85 and A_He = 4.2% → Open Field → expect fast, steady wind from coronal hole, recurrent if sampled again in ~27 days, moderate space weather impact if colliding with preceding slow wind. The classification's value extends beyond 1 AU: missions at different heliocentric distances (Parker Solar Probe at 0.1 AU, Ulysses at high latitudes, future probes at 0.05 AU) can apply the same scheme because |σ_c| and A_He are set close to the Sun (per Figure 2) and evolve predictably during propagation (|σ_c| decays, A_He remains constant), allowing calibration functions that map observed values back to source region values. The simplicity of the four-region scheme (compared to more complex classifications involving charge states, ion temperatures, or heavy element abundances) makes it accessible to non-specialists: satellite operators, power grid managers, and communication system planners can use this diagram to assess space weather risk from in situ measurements without requiring advanced degrees in plasma physics. The cartoon also identifies what's missing from traditional classification: the Transient region (upper-left) is often lumped with "slow wind" in speed-based schemes (since CMEs can have speeds <500 km/s) or with "ICMEs" in magnetic-topology schemes (requiring cloud identification), but here it's cleanly separated by composition (high A_He) without needing magnetic field signatures, enabling CME identification even when magnetic structures are weak or eroded. For coronal physics research, the four regions map to distinct source region models: Closed Field → helmet streamers and active region loops requiring intermittent release via reconnection; Open Field → stable coronal holes requiring steady Alfvénic acceleration; Mixed Source → coronal hole boundaries and interchange reconnection sites; Transients → erupting flux ropes and CME source regions. Testing these associations requires coordinating in situ measurements (classifying wind using this diagram) with remote sensing (identifying source regions via coronal imaging), a key goal for Parker Solar Probe and Solar Orbiter joint observations. Finally, the cartoon's "suggestive" nature (noted in the caption) acknowledges this is interpretation, not data—the boundaries are drawn where Figure 10's contours suggest transitions occur, but reasonable scientists might draw slightly different boundaries (e.g., placing the Closed/Mixed boundary at |σ_c| = 0.4 versus 0.5), and future work with larger datasets or different solar cycle phases may refine these regions. The grayed v_s band particularly emphasizes this uncertainty, indicating the exact location of compositional saturation within the Mixed Source region remains somewhat ambiguous and likely sample-dependent.
